abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Sector Reform
            Project (ESRP) for Chad were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was low or substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the Chad ESRP original results framework was weak with only
            one Project Development Objective (PDO) indicator out of
            seven specific to the project intervention (the other six
            were meant to measure increases on a national scale) and the
            intermediate outcome indicators included some measures of
            activities that were not funded by the Project. Overall,
            this resulted in the adoption of indicators which were not
            well-aligned with project components, hindering the Bank and
            the Government's ability to effectively measure
            progress of the Project. Improving capacity requires
            training on a continuous basis and a strong Technical
            Assistance (TA) sub-component. The ESRP provided sound TA
            and training to the CNC (Centre National des Curricula -
            National Curricula Center) technical staff which was
            supported over an extended period of time. This increased
            the impact of the training and has had a lasting influence
            on improved capacity. The challenge being faced now is
            limiting staff turn-over and renewal of staff contracts to
            ensure continuity and sustainability. Although design
            problems were identified earlier and discussed extensively
            with the Government, it was only two years after the
            Mid-Term Review (MTR) that restructuring was finalized when
            74 percent of the funds were already disbursed. Project
            restructuring might have been undertaken earlier which would
            have provided a greater opportunity to achieve better outcomes.

repnme.cdata!: Chad - Education Sector Reform Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Education Sector
            Reform Project for Chad is to assist the Borrower in
            developing its policy framework, strategies and means for
            achievement of quality universal basic education and
            implementing its strategy to improve access to and equity of
            education. The restructured project will focus on
            addressing: (i) access and equity related issues; and (ii)
            the weak capacity to manage the education system. The
            project's components have been reduced to two and the
            sub-components are reorganized and regrouped in line with
            the two new components and their number reduced from 18 to
            9. Some of the original subcomponents that have marginal
            effects on the overall education system will be dropped.
            Finally the project restructuring will align the project
            activities with the changes in the school construction
            program that is being implemented under the Government
            social infrastructure construction program, financed through
            the oil revenue budget. The results framework is revised to
            reflect the change in project development objective and the
            new target values for some indicators, as agreed during the
            mid-term review. The restructuring also proposes to extend
            the closing date from December 2010 to June 2012. This is a
            level one restructuring, which requires a Board approval.

repnme.cdata!:
Chad - Education Sector Reform Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA)
            identifies potential adverse impacts on the environment, as
            a result of construction, and rehabilitation activities,
            which include soil erosion, land, and water pollution due to
            improper waste disposal, and, loss of vegetative cover.
            Moreover, social impacts are likely to occur, namely health
            issues due to exposure to dust, noise, and traffic
            accidents. However, the EA specifies that land acquisition
            or loss of income are not expected as a result of schools
            construction. The EA recommends the use of standard
            environmental guidelines, including community participation
            in the process for re-vegetation propagation. Mitigation
            measures address the need to establish one primary
            decantation basin for each ten sand washers, as well as
            restoration of borrow pits, and provision of latrines. The
            use of cement and metal frames is strongly recommended to
            prevent vector diseases, in line with sanitation
            technologies. Appropriate site selection should identify the
            location of water effluents, to include as well water
            quality testing. During construction, soil surfaces should
            be protected, ensuring adequate drainage from gutters, and
            from wastewater collection points, while wastes, and solid
            waste management control should be ensured through disposal
            services. Public, and educational campaigns will contribute
            to improved health, through the provision of health and
            hygiene measures. Monitoring criteria should ensure that
            appropriate mitigation is being conducted.

repnme.cdata!:
Chad - Restructuring of the Education
            Sector Reform Project : environmental and social management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The revised target of the Education
            Sector Reform Project of Chad is to improve access and
            equity of the education system and to develop institutional
            capacity. This goal is in line with the state policy
            contained in the National Strategy for Growth and Reduction
            of Poverty which states that all children should be ensured
            a primary education of universal quality, eliminating
            disparities in access to education, health, nutrition and
            non-farm employment and establishing social safety nets
            needed to improve living conditions of street children, the
            disabled, women, old persons and other outcasts of society.
            The negative environmental impacts of the project result
            from construction of latrines and water points in terms of
            disruption of living conditions, and production of solid and
            liquid waste. The exploitation of quarries for extraction of
            construction materials could also be sources of negative
            impacts to the environment, which will require restorative
            actions after use. Environmental impacts such as soil
            erosion, pollution of soil and water, loss of vegetation,
            and impacts due to increased waste solids and liquids may
            come from the activities of construction of latrines and
            wells and the opening and operation of quarries for building
            materials. In the preparation phase of construction, the
            impacts are related to cutting trees to clear the targeted
            sites and extraction of construction materials and building
            waste. In short, direct and indirect effects are expected
            from: the pollution caused by uncontrolled discharge of
            solid and liquid waste, noise, dust, risk of accidents, soil
            erosion, and the likely reduction of vegetation cover in the
            area allowed for construction or operation of quarries.
